events.title: Jamestown Settlement
events.description: The first permanent English settlement in North America was established at Jamestown, Virginia. The Virginia Company sponsored the colony for economic profit.
events.why: England wanted to establish colonies in the New World to compete with Spain and France for resources, wealth, and territory while expanding their empire.

events.title: Plymouth Colony & Mayflower Compact
events.description: The Pilgrims landed at Plymouth and created the Mayflower Compact, an early example of self-government and rule by the consent of the governed.
events.why: The Pilgrims, seeking religious freedom, accidentally landed north of their intended Virginia destination and needed to establish legitimate governance outside the Virginia Company's territory.

events.title: Georgia Colony Established
events.description: James Oglethorpe founded Georgia as the 13th and final British colony in North America, initially as a haven for debtors and the 'worthy poor.'
events.why: Georgia was intended as both a philanthropic refuge for the poor and a strategic buffer colony to protect the valuable Carolinas from Spanish Florida.

events.title: French and Indian War Begins
events.description: Conflict erupted between British colonists and French forces (with Native American allies) over control of the Ohio River Valley.
events.why: Both Britain and France wanted to control this resource-rich territory, leading to what became part of the larger Seven Years' War.

events.title: End of French and Indian War
events.description: The Treaty of Paris ended the French and Indian War, with France ceding its North American territory to Britain and Spain.
events.why: Britain's victory dramatically changed North America's political landscape and left Britain with enormous war debts that would lead to new colonial taxes.

events.title: Sugar Act
events.description: Britain imposed the Sugar Act, taxing molasses and sugar imported to the colonies to help pay war debts.
events.why: Britain needed to generate revenue to pay for the French and Indian War and to finance the administration of its newly expanded North American empire.

events.title: Stamp Act Crisis
events.description: The British Parliament passed the Stamp Act, requiring colonists to pay a tax on every piece of printed paper they used, sparking widespread protests.
events.why: Britain continued to seek ways to generate revenue from the colonies, but colonists objected to being taxed without having representatives in Parliament.

events.title: Boston Tea Party
events.description: Colonists disguised as Native Americans dumped 342 chests of British tea into Boston Harbor to protest British tax policies.
events.why: The Tea Act granted the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales, undercutting colonial merchants while maintaining the tea tax that symbolized Parliament's authority to tax colonists without representation.

events.title: Intolerable Acts
events.description: Britain passed the Coercive Acts (called 'Intolerable Acts' by colonists) to punish Massachusetts after the Boston Tea Party, closing Boston Harbor and restricting town meetings.
events.why: Parliament wanted to assert its authority and punish Massachusetts for the destruction of British property, but these harsh measures only united the colonies further against Britain.

events.title: Battles of Lexington and Concord
events.description: The first military engagements of the American Revolutionary War occurred at Lexington and Concord, Massachusetts.
events.why: British troops were sent to confiscate colonial weapons and arrest leaders, but colonial militias were warned by Paul Revere and others, leading to armed resistance.

events.title: Second Continental Congress
events.description: Delegates from the colonies met in Philadelphia and established the Continental Army with George Washington as commander.
events.why: With fighting underway, the colonies needed to organize a unified military response and coordinate their resistance to British authority.

events.title: Declaration of Independence
events.description: The Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, written primarily by Thomas Jefferson, formally announcing the colonies' separation from Great Britain.
events.why: After years of increasing tensions and with reconciliation seeming impossible, colonial leaders decided to formally declare independence to gain international recognition and support.

events.title: Battle of Saratoga
events.description: American forces defeated British troops in upstate New York in what is considered the turning point of the Revolutionary War.
events.why: This major American victory convinced France to formally ally with the Americans against Britain, providing crucial military and financial support.

events.title: Battle of Yorktown
events.description: General Washington's forces, with French assistance, defeated British General Cornwallis at Yorktown, Virginia, effectively ending major fighting in the Revolutionary War.
events.why: After years of war and facing a combined American-French force, Britain was no longer able to sustain its military campaign in North America.

events.title: Treaty of Paris
events.description: Great Britain formally recognized American independence in the Treaty of Paris, which established boundaries and addressed other post-war issues.
events.why: After the military defeat at Yorktown and facing war with multiple European powers, Britain accepted American independence and sought to establish peaceful relations.

events.title: Articles of Confederation
events.description: The first constitution of the United States established a loose confederation of states with a weak central government.
events.why: Having just fought against a strong central authority (the British monarchy), Americans were cautious about creating another powerful central government.

events.title: Constitutional Convention
events.description: Delegates met in Philadelphia to revise the Articles of Confederation but instead created an entirely new constitution with a stronger federal government.
events.why: The Articles of Confederation proved inadequate for governing the nation, with problems including inability to collect taxes, regulate trade, or enforce laws.

events.title: Constitution Ratified
events.description: The Constitution was ratified by the required nine states, establishing the framework for the U.S. government that continues today.
events.why: The Federalist Papers and the promise to add a Bill of Rights helped persuade states to ratify the Constitution despite concerns about centralized power.

events.title: Washington's Presidency
events.description: George Washington was unanimously elected as the first President of the United States under the new Constitution.
events.why: As the respected leader of the Continental Army, Washington was trusted to establish precedents for the new office without becoming a monarch.

events.title: Bill of Rights Added
events.description: The first ten amendments to the Constitution, known as the Bill of Rights, were ratified to protect individual liberties.
events.why: Many states had demanded these protections as a condition for ratifying the Constitution, fearing the new government might abuse its power.

events.title: Whiskey Rebellion
events.description: Farmers in western Pennsylvania protested a tax on whiskey, and President Washington sent militia forces to suppress the rebellion.
events.why: This crisis tested the new government's authority to enforce federal law and collect taxes, demonstrating the strength of the federal government.

events.title: Louisiana Purchase
events.description: President Thomas Jefferson purchased the Louisiana Territory from France for $15 million, doubling the size of the United States.
events.why: Jefferson wanted to secure American access to the Mississippi River and the port of New Orleans, but Napoleon offered to sell the entire territory as France needed funds for European wars.

events.title: Lewis and Clark Expedition
events.description: Meriwether Lewis and William Clark led an expedition to explore the newly acquired Louisiana Territory and find a route to the Pacific Ocean.
events.why: Jefferson wanted to learn about the geography, natural resources, and native peoples of the western territories while establishing an American claim to the Pacific Northwest.

events.title: War of 1812
events.description: The United States went to war with Great Britain over maritime issues and western expansion, culminating in the British burning Washington D.C. and the Battle of New Orleans.
events.why: Britain was impressing American sailors and allegedly encouraging Native American resistance to western settlement during the Napoleonic Wars.

events.title: Monroe Doctrine
events.description: President James Monroe declared that European powers should no longer colonize or interfere with the affairs of independent nations in the Americas.
events.why: The United States wanted to prevent European powers from reestablishing colonies in the Americas while asserting itself as the dominant power in the Western Hemisphere.

events.title: Indian Removal Act
events.description: Congress passed the Indian Removal Act, authorizing the president to negotiate with southern Native American tribes for their removal to federal territory west of the Mississippi River.
events.why: White settlers wanted Native American lands for farming and gold mining, and President Jackson supported removal despite Supreme Court rulings in favor of Native American sovereignty.

events.title: Trail of Tears
events.description: The U.S. Army forcibly removed the Cherokee and other tribes from their southeastern homelands, resulting in thousands of deaths during the journey to Oklahoma Territory.
events.why: Despite winning their case in the Supreme Court, the Cherokee were forced from their lands because President Jackson refused to enforce the Court's decision and Georgia was determined to remove them.

events.title: Compromise of 1850
events.description: A series of bills admitted California as a free state, established the territories of New Mexico and Utah, ended the slave trade in Washington D.C., and enacted a stronger Fugitive Slave Act.
events.why: The compromise temporarily eased tensions over slavery's expansion into western territories, balancing free and slave state interests to preserve the Union.

events.title: Uncle Tom's Cabin Published
events.description: Harriet Beecher Stowe's novel about the harsh realities of slavery became a bestseller and influenced northern attitudes toward slavery.
events.why: The book humanized enslaved people and illustrated the cruelties of slavery, helping to shift northern public opinion against the institution.

events.title: Kansas-Nebraska Act
events.description: This law organized the territories of Kansas and Nebraska and repealed the Missouri Compromise by allowing popular sovereignty to determine whether slavery would be allowed.
events.why: Senator Stephen Douglas wanted to organize these territories to facilitate a transcontinental railroad, but the slavery provisions reignited sectional tensions.

events.title: Dred Scott Decision
events.description: The Supreme Court ruled that African Americans could not be citizens and that Congress could not prohibit slavery in the territories.
events.why: The Court tried to resolve the slavery issue permanently but instead intensified sectional conflict by invalidating compromises and supporting southern views of slavery.

events.title: John Brown's Raid
events.description: Abolitionist John Brown led a raid on the federal arsenal at Harpers Ferry, Virginia, hoping to start a slave uprising.
events.why: Brown believed violent action was necessary to end slavery, and while his raid failed, it increased southern fears of slave rebellions and northern support for abolition.

events.title: Lincoln Elected President
events.description: Abraham Lincoln, a Republican opposed to slavery's expansion, was elected president without winning any southern states.
events.why: Lincoln's election convinced southern states they had lost political power in the federal government and could no longer protect slavery within the Union.

events.title: South Carolina Secedes
events.description: South Carolina became the first state to secede from the Union following Lincoln's election.
events.why: South Carolina saw Lincoln's election as a threat to slavery and believed states had the right to leave the Union if the federal government threatened their interests.

events.title: Civil War Begins
events.description: Confederate forces fired on Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor, beginning the Civil War.
events.why: After several states seceded to form the Confederacy, tensions escalated over federal property in southern states, leading to military conflict.

events.title: Emancipation Proclamation
events.description: President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, declaring that all enslaved people in Confederate-controlled areas were to be set free.
events.why: Lincoln issued the proclamation as a military measure to weaken the Confederacy, shift the war's focus to include ending slavery, and prevent European powers from supporting the South.

events.title: Battle of Gettysburg
events.description: Union forces defeated the Confederate army at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, in the war's bloodiest battle and a major turning point.
events.why: General Lee had invaded the North hoping for a decisive victory that might convince the Union to make peace, but instead suffered a defeat that permanently weakened Confederate offensive capabilities.

events.title: Civil War Ends
events.description: General Robert E. Lee surrendered to General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, effectively ending the Civil War.
events.why: After four years of fighting, the Confederacy was exhausted of resources and manpower, with its major cities captured and armies defeated by the Union's superior numbers and industrial might.

events.title: Lincoln Assassinated
events.description: President Lincoln was shot by John Wilkes Booth at Ford's Theatre and died the next morning.
events.why: Booth, a Confederate sympathizer, hoped to disrupt the Union government and potentially revive the Confederate cause by killing Lincoln and other government officials.

events.title: 13th Amendment Ratified
events.description: The 13th Amendment to the Constitution was ratified, abolishing slavery throughout the United States.
events.why: The amendment was necessary to ensure that slavery ended everywhere in the United States, including border states that had remained in the Union and areas not covered by the Emancipation Proclamation.

events.title: 14th Amendment Ratified
events.description: The 14th Amendment granted citizenship to all persons born or naturalized in the United States, including former slaves, and guaranteed equal protection under the law.
events.why: Congress sought to constitutionally protect the civil rights of former slaves and prevent former Confederate states from denying these rights through discriminatory state laws.

events.title: 15th Amendment Ratified
events.description: The 15th Amendment prohibited denying citizens the right to vote based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude.
events.why: This amendment sought to guarantee political rights for African American men and prevent states from explicitly using race to deny voting rights.

events.title: Spanish-American War
events.description: The United States defeated Spain in a brief war, gaining control of territories including Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines.
events.why: The war began after the explosion of the USS Maine in Havana Harbor, with American involvement driven by sympathy for Cuban independence, business interests, and sensationalist newspaper coverage.

events.title: Theodore Roosevelt Becomes President
events.description: Following the assassination of President McKinley, Theodore Roosevelt became the youngest president in American history at age 42.
events.why: Roosevelt's dynamic leadership style transformed the presidency, expanding executive power and American influence abroad while pursuing progressive domestic reforms.

events.title: Wright Brothers' First Flight
events.description: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first powered, controlled aircraft flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
events.why: This technological breakthrough launched the aviation age, revolutionizing transportation, warfare, and global connections in the 20th century.

events.title: Panama Canal Opens
events.description: The Panama Canal opened, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and revolutionizing maritime transportation.
events.why: The canal dramatically shortened shipping routes, strengthened American naval power by allowing faster fleet movement between oceans, and demonstrated American engineering and geopolitical influence.

events.title: U.S. Enters World War I
events.description: The United States entered World War I on the side of the Allied Powers after years of neutrality.
events.why: German submarine warfare against American ships and the Zimmermann Telegram (proposing a German alliance with Mexico against the US) convinced President Wilson to enter the war despite earlier neutrality pledges.

events.title: World War I Ends
events.description: World War I ended with an Allied victory after more than four years of brutal conflict.
events.why: American troops helped break the stalemate on the Western Front, while Germany's resources were exhausted and its allies defeated, leading to an armistice and eventually the Treaty of Versailles.

events.title: Treaty of Versailles
events.description: The Treaty of Versailles officially ended World War I and established the League of Nations, though the U.S. Senate rejected American membership.
events.why: President Wilson sought a 'peace without victory' and a new international order through his Fourteen Points, but domestic opposition to foreign entanglements and concerns about sovereignty prevented U.S. ratification.

events.title: Stock Market Crash
events.description: The stock market crashed on 'Black Tuesday,' triggering the Great Depression, the worst economic crisis in U.S. history.
events.why: Overspeculation in stocks, excessive borrowing, uneven distribution of wealth, overproduction of goods, and weak banking regulations created an unsustainable bubble that finally burst.

events.title: Franklin D. Roosevelt Elected
events.description: Franklin D. Roosevelt defeated Herbert Hoover in a landslide election, promising a 'New Deal' to address the Great Depression.
events.why: Hoover's perceived failure to effectively address the Depression and Roosevelt's message of hope and action resonated with voters suffering from economic hardship.

events.title: New Deal Begins
events.description: President Roosevelt launched numerous programs and agencies to provide relief, recovery, and reform during the Great Depression.
events.why: Roosevelt believed government intervention was necessary to address the economic crisis, putting people to work, regulating the economy, and providing a safety net for vulnerable Americans.

events.title: Social Security Act
events.description: The Social Security Act established a system of old-age benefits, unemployment insurance, and aid to families with dependent children.
events.why: The economic insecurity revealed by the Depression convinced many Americans that government should provide a safety net to protect vulnerable citizens from poverty in old age or during economic downturns.

events.title: World War II Begins in Europe
events.description: Germany invaded Poland, beginning World War II in Europe, though the United States remained officially neutral.
events.why: Nazi Germany under Adolf Hitler pursued aggressive expansion to gain 'living space,' rebuild German power, and dominate Europe, while other nations initially tried to avoid war through appeasement.

events.title: Pearl Harbor Attack
events.description: Japan attacked the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing more than 2,400 Americans and destroying numerous ships and aircraft.
events.why: Japan sought to neutralize the U.S. Pacific Fleet to prevent American interference with its expansion in Asia, as U.S. economic sanctions had restricted Japan's access to oil and other resources.

events.title: Japanese American Internment
events.description: The U.S. government forced over 120,000 Japanese Americans, most of them U.S. citizens, into internment camps.
events.why: After Pearl Harbor, fear, prejudice, and wartime hysteria led to suspicion of Japanese Americans' loyalty, resulting in this mass violation of civil liberties despite no evidence of widespread disloyalty.

events.title: D-Day Invasion
events.description: Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy, France, beginning the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control.
events.why: This massive amphibious invasion established a crucial Western Front, forcing Germany to fight on multiple fronts and accelerating the defeat of Nazi Germany.

events.title: Atomic Bombs & End of WWII
events.description: The United States dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, leading to Japan's surrender and the end of World War II.
events.why: President Truman authorized using these new weapons to avoid a costly invasion of Japan that military planners estimated would cause hundreds of thousands of American and millions of Japanese casualties.

events.title: United Nations Established
events.description: The United Nations was founded to maintain international peace and security, develop friendly relations among nations, and promote social progress.
events.why: After two devastating world wars, nations sought to create an effective international organization that could prevent future conflicts through collective security and cooperation.

events.title: Truman Doctrine
events.description: President Truman announced that the United States would provide political, military, and economic assistance to democratic nations under threat from external or internal authoritarian forces.
events.why: The Soviet Union was expanding its influence in Eastern Europe and pressuring countries like Greece and Turkey, leading Truman to articulate a policy of containing communism.

events.title: Berlin Airlift
events.description: When the Soviet Union blockaded West Berlin, the United States and its allies airlifted food, fuel, and supplies to the isolated city for nearly a year.
events.why: The Soviets blocked land access to West Berlin (located inside Soviet-controlled East Germany) to force the Allies out, but the airlift allowed Berlin to survive without military confrontation.

events.title: Korean War Begins
events.description: North Korea invaded South Korea, beginning a three-year conflict in which the United States led UN forces supporting South Korea.
events.why: Communist North Korea, supported by the Soviet Union and China, sought to unify the Korean peninsula under communist rule, while the U.S. intervened to contain communist expansion in Asia.

events.title: Brown v. Board of Education
events.description: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional, overturning the 'separate but equal' doctrine.
events.why: The NAACP and African American parents challenged segregated schools, and the Court concluded that separate educational facilities were inherently unequal and violated the 14th Amendment.

events.title: Montgomery Bus Boycott
events.description: African Americans in Montgomery, Alabama boycotted the city buses for over a year after Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat to a white passenger.
events.why: African Americans were tired of segregation and unequal treatment on public transportation. The boycott became a pivotal moment in the Civil Rights Movement and launched Martin Luther King Jr. as a national leader.

events.title: Little Rock Nine
events.description: Nine African American students faced angry mobs when attempting to integrate Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, requiring federal troops to protect them.
events.why: Despite the Brown v. Board decision, many southern states resisted school integration. President Eisenhower had to send federal troops to enforce the law when the Arkansas governor used the National Guard to block integration.

events.title: Cuban Missile Crisis
events.description: The United States and Soviet Union came to the brink of nuclear war after the U.S. discovered Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.
events.why: The Soviet Union placed missiles in Cuba to counter U.S. missiles in Turkey and to protect Cuba from another U.S.-backed invasion attempt after the failed Bay of Pigs invasion.

events.title: March on Washington
events.description: More than 250,000 people participated in a march for jobs and freedom in Washington, D.C., where Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his famous 'I Have a Dream' speech.
events.why: Civil rights leaders organized the march to pressure Congress to pass civil rights legislation and to bring national attention to the ongoing struggle for racial equality and economic justice.

events.title: Civil Rights Act
events.description: Congress passed the Civil Rights Act, prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin in public accommodations, facilities, and schools.
events.why: After years of civil rights activism, televised images of police brutality against peaceful protesters, and President Kennedy's assassination, President Johnson used his political skills to pass this landmark legislation.

events.title: Voting Rights Act
events.description: The Voting Rights Act outlawed discriminatory voting practices that had been used to disenfranchise African Americans, particularly in the South.
events.why: Despite the 15th Amendment, many states used literacy tests, poll taxes, and intimidation to prevent African Americans from voting. TV coverage of violence against voting rights marchers in Selma, Alabama helped build support for the law.

events.title: Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.
events.description: Civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee, sparking riots in many American cities.
events.why: King's assassination removed a powerful advocate for nonviolent social change and reflected the violent resistance to the civil rights movement, devastating communities and leaving a leadership void.

events.title: Moon Landing
events.description: American astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the moon during the Apollo 11 mission.
events.why: The space race began as a Cold War competition after the Soviet Union launched Sputnik in 1957. President Kennedy had set a goal to reach the moon by the end of the 1960s, and Apollo 11 fulfilled that vision.

events.title: End of Vietnam War for U.S.
events.description: The United States signed the Paris Peace Accords, ending direct U.S. military involvement in the Vietnam War.
events.why: After years of escalating U.S. involvement and mounting casualties, domestic opposition to the war and the failure to achieve decisive military victory led to a negotiated withdrawal.

events.title: Nixon Resigns
events.description: President Richard Nixon resigned following the Watergate scandal, becoming the only U.S. president to resign from office.
events.why: Investigations revealed Nixon's involvement in covering up a break-in at Democratic National Committee headquarters and other abuses of power, leading to impeachment proceedings and his resignation.

events.title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
events.description: The Berlin Wall, which had divided East and West Berlin since 1961, was opened as East Germany's communist government allowed citizens to cross freely into West Berlin.
events.why: Reforms in the Soviet Union, peaceful protests throughout Eastern Europe, and East Germany's failing economy led to the collapse of communist authority and the opening of the border.

events.title: Dissolution of the Soviet Union
events.description: The Soviet Union formally dissolved, ending the Cold War and creating 15 independent nations from the former Soviet republics.
events.why: Economic problems, nationalist movements in Soviet republics, failed reforms, and the collapse of communist regimes in Eastern Europe led to the breakup of the Soviet Union.

events.title: Gulf War
events.description: The United States led a coalition of nations to liberate Kuwait after Iraq invaded and annexed it.
events.why: Iraq invaded Kuwait to seize its oil wealth and resolve border disputes. The U.S. and allies intervened to defend Kuwait's sovereignty and protect oil supplies.

events.title: September 11 Attacks
events.description: Terrorists hijacked four commercial airplanes, crashing two into the World Trade Center in New York City, one into the Pentagon, and one in Pennsylvania after passengers fought back.
events.why: The terrorist group al-Qaeda, led by Osama bin Laden, attacked America due to opposition to U.S. military presence in the Middle East, support for Israel, and other grievances against American foreign policy.

events.title: War in Afghanistan
events.description: After the 9/11 attacks, the United States invaded Afghanistan to dismantle al-Qaeda and remove the Taliban government that had sheltered them.
events.why: The Taliban refused to hand over Osama bin Laden and other al-Qaeda leaders responsible for the 9/11 attacks, leading the U.S. to take military action.

events.title: Iraq War Begins
events.description: The United States led an invasion of Iraq, quickly toppling Saddam Hussein's government but becoming involved in a lengthy occupation and insurgency.
events.why: The Bush administration claimed Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction and had links to terrorism, though these claims proved unfounded. Other motives included establishing democracy in the Middle East and securing oil supplies.

events.title: Hurricane Katrina
events.description: Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans and the Gulf Coast, becoming one of the deadliest and most costly natural disasters in U.S. history.
events.why: The powerful hurricane overwhelmed levees protecting New Orleans, while inadequate evacuation plans and a slow, disorganized government response contributed to the high death toll and widespread suffering.

events.title: Great Recession
events.description: The worst economic downturn since the Great Depression began with the collapse of the housing market and several major financial institutions.
events.why: The crisis stemmed from risky mortgage lending practices, complex financial derivatives, inadequate regulation, and excessive risk-taking by financial institutions.

events.title: Election of Barack Obama
events.description: Barack Obama was elected as the first African American president of the United States.
events.why: Obama's message of hope and change resonated with voters during the economic crisis, and his election represented a historic milestone in a nation that had once permitted slavery and segregation.

events.title: Affordable Care Act
events.description: Congress passed the Affordable Care Act, the most significant overhaul of the U.S. healthcare system since Medicare and Medicaid in the 1960s.
events.why: The law aimed to expand healthcare coverage to millions of uninsured Americans, control healthcare costs, and improve healthcare quality through insurance reforms and subsidies.

events.title: Osama bin Laden Killed
events.description: U.S. special forces killed Osama bin Laden, the leader of al-Qaeda and mastermind of the September 11 attacks, in a raid on his compound in Pakistan.
events.why: After nearly a decade of searching, intelligence located bin Laden's hideout, and President Obama authorized the raid to bring the 9/11 mastermind to justice.

events.title: Same-Sex Marriage Legalized
events.description: The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that the fundamental right to marry is guaranteed to same-sex couples.
events.why: After decades of LGBTQ+ activism and evolving public opinion, the Court determined that denying marriage rights to same-sex couples violated the Constitution's equal protection and due process clauses.

events.title: COVID-19 Pandemic
events.description: The COVID-19 pandemic caused a global health crisis, with the United States experiencing hundreds of thousands of deaths and major economic disruption.
events.why: The highly contagious novel coronavirus spread worldwide, overwhelming healthcare systems and forcing unprecedented lockdowns and public health measures to contain its spread.

events.title: January 6 Capitol Riot
events.description: Protesters violently stormed the U.S. Capitol to disrupt the certification of the 2020 presidential election results.
events.why: Following the 2020 election, some supporters of President Trump believed false claims of widespread election fraud and attempted to prevent the peaceful transfer of power.
